(Also, the 4000 series was even MORE expensive here. None of them were affordable at any point; they went out of stock at high prices - the 4070 Ti Super's lowest point is still more expensive than the price I just paid).

comments.author: @Jonathan.mp4

comments.text:
I got the Gigabyte RTX 5070 Ti Gaming for 1150 in my country. 
The 4000s were not well priced and the used card market did not have any good deals. I am very happy with the card although it was expensive. 
Comparing it with 4080/4090 is kind of pointless, because I did not find any good deals on those. It had the best value if not buying an old 3070 or something.
comments.author: @RainHallikas

comments.text:
As someone who has been watching their 10G 3080 absolutely melt trying to play 4K ray tracing games, this card seems like the best choice given the price of the 5080, 4090 and 4080 super and lackluster 7900xtx and 9700xt 4k ray tracing performance.

I don't care if it's not a good value.  Everything is expensive but at the $999 MSRP I got my ASUS TUF OC 5070TI at, I honestly don't mind.  I waited all last gen and prices were crazy.  I waited this gen and prices are crazy.  It's not going to stop and my backlog of games I want to play with RTX isn't getting any shorter.

$1000 to effectively double or triple my FPS?  I'll take it.
comments.author: @FastRedPonyCar

My Asus 5070ti Prime OC edition was $900. While I'm not thrilled about the cost, this is the new reality. MSRP isn't going to happen again, while AI is as hot as it is.

BUYER BEWARE: Some of 5090 & 5070 Ti GPUs has fewer ROPs than specified. The average graphical performance impact is 4% slower.

 RTX 5070 Ti = 96 ROPs (Affected units have 88 ROPs)

comments.text:
With hindsight in mind, do you regret the video you made a couple months back telling consumers to not buy a discounted GPU during the Black Friday sales at the end of November and instead wait for the 50 series?

By that point US tariffs were already being promised and with the looming likelihood of an economic downturn on the horizon, I went against your own advice and bought a 4070 Ti Super for what's now likely to be its all-time lowest pricing at ~$685 USD (came out to closer to $635 after cashback stacking). Time seems to have vindicated me in this decision, but even if the 50-series' launch wasn't at the same level of disaster it's been so far, it seems like much of this could have been predicted just looking at the launch data from the last two generations, particularly the economic-political context of the 30-series launch.

comments.text: talk about why rops/tmu in modern gpu is disregarded heavily. shader cores are not the main gpu, its just the shader part of the pipeline. therefore the shader teraflops is not the graphics teraflops. because shader does not have to do any of the basic transforms or texture mapping. if you use default shader that just copies the texture color then you get the rops/tmu only part pipeline of the gpu, shaders doing nothing. who said you need to shade. just use baked textures. shaders are for effects. blackwell drivers are bad. bug fixed required.

comments.text: That's because we already have tariffs (of a sort) in place - customs duties. Take the 750 USD MSRP, at the current exchange rate of about 63 US cents to the dollar that's about 1200 AUD. Multiply by 1.1 for the GST - 1320 AUD. Then multiply by another 1.1 for the customs duty that the retailer has to pay the ABF in order to import the goods, which they will of course pass on to the customer, and the equivalent MSRP for us is about 1452 AUD.

comments.text:
This is the WORST release by NVidia possibly ever. Worse than the COVID scalper release of the 30-series. AT LEAST the 30-series was a big improvement over the 20-series.
The cards were sparsely available on release, with some retailers claiming low double-digits as their initial stock - the same retailers got HUNDREDS of 30/40-series GPUs on launch - that's insane.  The pricing being spiked by "Tariffs" makes it worse too.
I can't remember a launch this bad from a pure-launch/pricing/'stock availability point.  The 30-series availability was at least somewhat combated by eVGA's queue system... now that they're dead (thanks to NVidia) when it comes to the GPU market, there's really nowhere to turn to.
The prices are higher, and the performance to price ratio is UNCHANGED.
There's literally zero positives to this series of GPUs, MFG is borderline useless, not in enough games, and it looks like trash 75% of the time in most use cases. 
Glad I took the plunge and got an RTX 4090 with a thicc-arse cooler with 0% interest for 12 months when I did, got it at slightly over launch MSRP for the model I bought, paid it off with time to spare, and it's worth more now than what I paid for it new well over a year ago.  I'll be keeping it til NVidia releases something worth buying again.
The only appeal the 5090 has for me is the 32GB VRAM buffer as I do rendering work on occasion that could use that extra 8GB of VRAM, but that is not worth the price premium or trying to snipe one out from under scalpers.
comments.author: @Ereshkigal_1

comments.text: A great review as always Steve. The GPU vertical all got drunk during the 'party time' of GPU mining. As we all know. for miners a GPU was the way to make money so their purchasing decision was a straight forward time of return on investment - and we saw lots and lots and lots and lots and lots of GPUS sold via multiple ways other than retail channels into the hands of miners - some of them huge commercial operations. The poor individual gamer relying on availability through the standard retail channel never got a look in as they were never 'in the know'. The GPU vertical still want the party days to continue (of course - great for profitability) and they have found it now in AI. Again the individual gamer who's purchasing decision is vastly different from a return of investment calc, is again the loser. However, some of us never learn and we still keep buying these GPUs at ever increasing prices. I wonder at what upper price limit gamers will finally realise they are being taken for a ride - seemingly we have not reached that price level yet?
comments.author: @bignishspcinsights1762

comments.text:
If AMD can't make a proper response to this.... PC gaming is going to die... People are tired of the bland nonsense games with forced narratives and unappealing characters, but there are stil a few rays of light here and there. If people feel like they have to get rectum reamed with a cactus for maybe 3 good games a year, they WILL find other hobbies. As a long term business strategy it is vital that AMD straps the belt all the way in and delivers a value king like the Ryzen 3600. The reason they sold by the buckets was because they were only a little worse than Intel's similar offering.... but they were a LOT cheaper.

Assuming the 9070XT is exactly on par with the 5070Ti in raster and, say, 10% slower when RT is cranked, and that FSR4 is reasonably comparable to DLSS3.5 in quality and performance, then it can't come in at a cent over $600... and it has to hit that price with at least 30% of the volume being base models. But due to mind share, realistically it has to hit $550. That's a clean "With us you're getting a full performance tier for free... take that Nvidia!". 

But the question is: Can AMD even do that? The die size is ~390mm2 which is slightly larger than GB203. On the same node. I'm not sure there's margin enough to cut into....

comments.text:
The GPU market is a bit of a mess right now. 
My last build was from 2016, so pretty dated. Built a new rig around the middle of last year but held off on a GPU, as I knew the 50 series was coming, with the 5080 on my mind. 
Towards the end of the year, before news came out about NVidia dropping production of the 40 series GPUs, cards here in NZ became near non existent. After the aforementioned announcement, they were all gone. 
Reviews came out, and the 5080 isn't that much better than a 4080. But for someone coming from quite a few generations behind (GTX1080), it's not like I could get a 4080, because there are non. Buy a used one? Because the 5080's are also scarce at the moment, and you can't buy new 4080's anymore, people are selling them on ebay for as much as 5080's are going for here at retail (When they eventually get them in stock). Not to mention, I'd have to pay an additional 15% import tax once it reaches the boarder. So buying used doesn't make sense. 
So if you're already on a 40 series card, just stay on a 40 series card. Even if the gen uplift was something like 40%, it doesn't make sense to upgrade unless you've got money to burn. 
If you're wanting to upgrade from a couple of generations, 50 series is probably your best bet. You're just gonna have to wait til there's more availability. That, or pay way more than you should for a 40 series, or way more than you should on scalper prices. 
It's sad, but that's just how it is at the moment

I would get AMD, if FSR would match the motion clarity of the new DLSS model, as that FINALLY gets rid of almost all the blurriness in modern games, which really, really annoys me, obligatory FUCK TAA. And if they had anything like RTX HDR, since not every game has either a native HDR implementation or can use Windows Auto HDR, even with the tool that can force it. 
E.g. Wuthering Waves, one of my most played games at the moment, which looks phenomal in HDR, I just couldnt play in HDR if I were to go AMD.

The GPU market sucks fucking ass. 

I have looked into repasting my 2070 Super, but I havent yet been able to find any information on the thermal pads it uses and I am pretty sure they are dunzo the moment I open my GPU...

comments.text:
@TheKwod It's important to notice, that it more than fulfills the requirements for RT. 7900 XTX performs better in terms of RT in games such as Dragon's Dogma II, Indiana Jones and Resident Evil 4, but not in games such as Cyberpunk2077 and Black Myth Wukong. What does this mean? It is more than sufficient for light and medium RT workloads and only becomes unusable for the super heavy RT workloads designed around Nvidia cards. 7900 XTX will still be able to play all modern games for the years to come, you'd only have to turn down the RT setting from Ultra to Medium or Low. But hey - you could always pay almost double the money for a 5080 and get a marginal performance increase!

In short - in the games where you HAVE to enable RT 7900 XTX performs well.
In the games where RT is a flagship feature for bragging rights - yea, it's not the best experience if you enable path tracing or Ultra RT, but is otherwise still usable. 

Personally, I use 7900 XTX on Linux and it performs extremely well. RT under Linux is not yet working properly (the performance isn't there yet, even with 4090), so it would be a waste of money for me to buy a Nvidia GPU + the Nvidia Linux drivers are terrible, while AMD's drivers are beyond great.

comments.author: @chrisward000

comments.text:
@chrisward000 That's just path tracing. Nothing nvidia sponsored necessary. You could make a path tracing mod for a game and it would run into the same issues on AMD simply because of the way they do their RT acceleration on their hardware (read: not even trying to dedicate proper silicon to it). It's just too many calculations. Even regular RT can put the XTX In between a 4070 Super and Ti.  Like just using hardware lumen In UE5, or any of the proprietary engines like Snowdrop or Northlight. Which is basically all of the games coming out. I think like 80% of games I play have RT nowadays.

It's likely AMD will not even try to do it properly until UDNA for the generation after 9000 which is likely because it's gearing up for console generation. AMD only cares about consoles.

RTX 5090 with 32GB GDDR7, NV do not want to sell these cards. They are too good at AI workloads. The main advantage of GDDR7 is AI.

We are the exit strategy. Terriiffs 10% bla bla bla. AIB's are Super Ti pissed. RTX 3000 paper launch was actual demand eating up all the cards being made. RTX 5000 is actually a paper launch where the silicon is going to AI.
 

The AIB partners makes money on selling cards. Making only enough cards for reviewers? The AIB's have paid and setup manufacturing and development of boards and cooler assembly. comments.text:
Framing it that way doesn't really make sense to me. Look at the CUDA cores across generations. 

3080 (10 GB) had 8704 cores. Then next generation, the 4070 Ti had 7680 cores. If there had been no generational improvement, that would make it 88% of a 3080. The 4060 Ti had 4352 cores (50% of a 3080). Obviously, the 4070 Ti outperforms the 3080, because architectural improvements and a smaller process node more than make up for the drop in CUDA count.

Now make the same comparison with the 4080. It had 9728 CUDA cores. The 5070 Ti has 8960 cores (92%). We don't know the 5060 Ti's configuration, but it must be less than the upcoming 5070's 6144 cores (63%). This is a similar "cross-generational cut-down" to the previous example. But this time it's on the same process node, with little, if any, improvement to the CUDA architecture. The VRAM is faster, but that's not enough to beat the 4080.

This is a stagnant generation, but that doesn't magically make this card "really" a 5060 Ti.

comments.text:
AMD MUST Price their new Cards as following:

9070XT = $499.99
9070 = $379.99

Any higher, and even IF the 9070XT performs like a 5080 and the 9070 performs like a 5070-Ti, people will just save a little more money  and get a Geforce card.
Evidence? Most people picked the GTX1050-Ti over the RX-570. Most people pick the RTX4060-Ti OVER the RX-7700XT.

AMD CAN do this, they did it before. The Radeon HD4870 for $299.99 was almost as fast as the $599.99 Geforce GTX280.  The HD4870 provided about 85% of the performance of the GTX280 for HALF the MSRP. AMD can do this again. Imagine IF the RX-9070XT repeated the HD4870?  AMD gained marketshare.

AMD has to STOP selling Corvettes at Lamborghini prices.  
If I wanted a sports car, and the Corvette was only 10% cheaper than the Lambo, I'd just save up the bit more for the Lambo, even IF the Lambo is slower than the Corvette. It's a Lambo.

That's the mentality people have with GPUs. AMD has to get it through their head, that if nVidia is Lamborghini, AMD is NOT Ferrari, they are Chevrolet. Price your product accordingly.
